raw_text:
'Post-Christmas lull' in lending
 
 UK mortgage lending showed a "post-Christmas lull" in January, indicating a slowing housing market, lenders have said.
 
 Both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) said lending was down sharply. The CML said gross mortgage lending stood at £17.9bn, compared with £21.8bn in January last year. The BSA said mortgage approvals - loans approved but not yet made - were £2bn, down from £2.6bn in January 2004.
 
 At the same time, the British Bankers' Association (BBA) said lending was "weaker". Overall, the BBA said mortgage lending rose by £4bn in January, a far smaller increase than the £5.1bn seen in December. This was a return to the "weaker pattern" of lending seen in the last months of 2004, the BBA added. However, it is the year-on-year lending comparisons which are the most striking. The CML said lending for house purchases and gross mortgage lending were 29% and 18% lower year-on-year respectively. "These figures show beyond doubt the recent slowdown in the housing market," Peter Williams, CML deputy director, said.
llama3.2:1b: UK mortgage lending fell sharply in January, with a £4bn increase, compared to a £5.1bn rise in December.
Gross mortgage lending was down 29% year-on-year, while house purchase lending and gross mortgage lending were down 18% year-on-year.
llama3.2:3b: UK mortgage lending decreased sharply in January compared to last year, with gross lending standing at £17.9bn and mortgage approvals at £2bn, down from 2004 levels.
Lending growth slowed significantly, with only a £4bn increase in January, and is now down 29% for house purchases and 18% overall from the same period last year.
gemma2:2b: Mortgage lending in the UK slowed significantly in January, with lower approvals and overall lending volumes compared to the previous year.
The decrease suggests a slowing housing market.
The Council of Mortgage Lenders reported 29% year-on-year drop in house purchases and 18% decline in gross mortgage lending.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key ideas:
- UK mortgage lending slowed in January
- Both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) reported a decrease in lending
- The British Bankers' Association (BBA) reported increased lending
- The CML's figures showed a 29% decline in house purchases and a 18% fall in gross mortgage lending, while the BBA's figures show a smaller increase of £4bn compared to December.
Summary: UK mortgage lending has slowed down significantly in January, with both CML and BSA reports showing a decrease.
However, the BBA claims a much smaller increase than expected, noting that the year-on-year comparison is more striking.
qwen2.5:1.5b: In January, UK mortgage lending showed a decline following Christmas, with both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) reporting lower loan volumes compared to January 2004.
The British Bankers' Association (BBA) also noted weaker overall mortgage lending in January, though year-on-year comparisons highlight more significant drops for house purchases and gross mortgages.
This downturn aligns with a previously observed pattern of slower lending seen at the end of 2004.
qwen2.5:3b: UK mortgage lending showed a 'post-Christmas lull' in January, with both the Council of Mortgage Lenders and Building Society Association reporting sharp decreases.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders stated that gross mortgage lending fell to £17.9bn from £21.8bn last year, while the Building Society Association reported mortgage approvals at £2bn, down from £2.6bn in 2004.
The British Bankers' Association noted that overall mortgage lending increased by £4bn in January but was a smaller rise compared to December's £5.1bn increase.

The BBA attributed this to returning 'weaker pattern' of lending seen in the last months of 2004, emphasizing year-on-year comparisons showing a significant drop of 29% for house purchases and 18% for gross mortgage lending.
CML deputy director Peter Williams stated that these figures unequivocally indicate a recent slowdown in the housing market.

MORTGAGE APPROVALS - LOANS APPROVED BUT NOT YET MADE: rose by £4bn in January, a far smaller increase than the £5.1bn seen in December.
Overall, mortgage lending rose by £4bn in January, a far smaller increase than the £5.1bn seen in December.
This was a return to the "weaker pattern" of lending seen in the last months of 2004.
The CML said lending for house purchases and gross mortgage lending were 29% and 18% lower year-on-year respectively.
"These figures show beyond doubt the recent slowdown in the housing market," Peter Williams, CML deputy director, said.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be:
'Post-Christmas lull in lending': The UK mortgage lending showed a 'post-Christmas lull' in January, indicating a slowing housing market, lenders have said.
Both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) said lending was down sharply.
The CML said gross mortgage lending stood at £17.9bn, compared with £21.8bn in January last year.
The BSA said mortgage approvals - loans approved but not yet made - were £2bn, down from £2.6bn in January 2004.
At the same time, the British Bankers' Association (BBA) said lending was "weaker".
Overall, the BBA said mortgage lending rose by £4bn in January, a far smaller increase than the £5.1bn seen in December.
This was a return to the 'weaker pattern' of lending seen in the last months of 2004, the BBA added.
However, it is the year-on-year lending comparisons which are the most striking.
The CML said lending for house purchases and gross mortgage lending were 29% and 18% lower year-on-year respectively.
"These figures show beyond doubt the recent slowdown in the housing market," Peter Williams, CML deputy director, said.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK mortgage lending experienced a "post-Christmas lull" in January, showing a notable decline following the holiday season.

Both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) reported that lending was significantly down, with CML stating gross mortgage lending stood at £17.9 billion, compared to £21.8 billion last year.
The BSA noted £2bn in mortgage approvals, a decrease from £2.6bn in 2004.

However, the British Bankers' Association (BBA) mentioned a weaker pattern of lending overall, with an increase of £4 billion, which was a return to previous issues but not as severe as seen in December.
CML highlighted a year-on-year decline: mortgage purchases and gross mortgage lending decreased by 29% and 18%, respectively.
Peter Williams from the CML emphasized these significant drops as evidence of a slowdown in the housing market.
tinyllama:1.1b: Summary: The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) reported a decline in gross mortgage lending in January 2005, compared to January 2004's figures.
Overall, the CML said lenning was "weak", with the British Bankers' Association (BBA) reporting a smaller increase than December's.
Lending for house purchase and gross mortgage lending stood at £17.9bn compared to £21.8bn in January 2004.
The BSA also reported a year-on-year decrease of 33% and 29%, respectively, which the CML attributed to the recent slowdown in the housing market.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK mortgage lending market experienced a slowing trend during January, according to both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA).
Gross mortgage lending was estimated at £17.9bn in January, down from the previous month's total of £21.8bn.
However, this decline was significantly less than the 24% decrease experienced in December, with approvals for loans worth over £2bn having dropped sharply to £2bn from £2.6bn a year prior.

The BBA's comparable figures for mortgage lending in January indicated a more modest 7% decline in lending compared to December, with the BBA estimating a rise of £4bn overall, reflecting a stronger trend in recent months.
However, this figure is significantly less than the £5.1bn seen in December, which was an increase of 38% over the previous month.
In contrast, the CML reported that lending for house purchases and gross mortgage lending were both down 29% year-on-year, while gross mortgage lending declined by 18% compared to January 2004.
Despite these comparable figures showing a moderation in the housing market's performance, the CML said that overall mortgage lending was weaker than the December figure of £21.8bn.
This pattern of lending activity is reflected by the comparable figures for the BSA, where approvals for loans worth over £2bn had risen to £2bn from £2.6bn in January 2004.
phi:2.7b: Mortgage lending in the UK saw a significant drop in January 2021 compared to January 2020, with gross mortgage lending at £17.9bn and mortgage approvals at £2bn, indicating a slowing housing market.
The trend of weaker lending is also seen in the year-on-year comparisons, which showed 29% and 18% decreases respectively for house purchases and gross mortgage lending.
orca-mini:3b: The UK mortgage lending market showed a "post-Christmas lull" with gross mortgage lending down by 29% and house purchases by 18%.
hermes3:3b: UK mortgage lending dropped in Jan, indicating slower housing market; CML & BSA said lending down sharply compared to last year.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: UK mortgage lending experienced a "post-Christmas lull" in January, with both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association (BSA) noting a significant drop in lending activities.
Gross mortgage lending amounted to £17.9 billion, down from £21.8 billion the previous year, while mortgage approvals were also lower at £2 billion, compared to £2.6 billion in January 2004.
The British Bankers' Association (BBA) reported a smaller increase of £4 billion in January, returning to the "weaker pattern" of lending observed towards the end of 2004.
CML Deputy Director Peter Williams attributed these figures to "beyond doubt [the] recent slowdown in the housing market."
chatgpt-4o-latest: UK mortgage lending experienced a "post-Christmas lull" in January, reflecting a slowing housing market.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) reported gross mortgage lending at £17.9bn, down from £21.8bn a year earlier, while the Building Society Association (BSA) noted a decline in mortgage approvals from £2.6bn to £2bn.
The British Bankers' Association (BBA) also described lending as "weaker," with mortgage lending rising by only £4bn in January compared to £5.1bn in December.
Year-on-year, lending for house purchases and gross mortgage lending fell by 29% and 18%, respectively.
CML deputy director Peter Williams confirmed the figures as clear evidence of a housing market slowdown.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK mortgage lending experienced a "post-Christmas lull" in January with both the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) and Building Society Association reporting declines in lending.
Gross mortgage lending dropped from £1.8bn to £1.9bn compared to last year's first month, while mortgage approvals were down by £2bn to £2bn.
The British Bankers' Association also noted a weaker pattern of lending.
House purchase and gross mortgage lending remained lower year-over-year at 20% and 21%, respectively, indicating a slowdown in the housing market according to CML deputy director, Peter Williams.
granite3.1-dense:2b: UK mortgage lending experienced a significant decrease in January, reflecting a slowdown in the housing market.
According to the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), gross mortgage lending dropped to £17.9bn from £21.8bn in January 2003.
The Building Society Association (BSA) reported a 26% decline in mortgage approvals, from £2.6bn to £2bn compared to January 2004.
Similarly, the British Bankers' Association (BBA) noted a £4bn increase in lending, but this was less than the £5.1bn seen in December, indicating a return to weaker lending patterns from late 2004.
Year-on-year comparisons were particularly stark: CML reported a 29% decrease in house purchase lending and an 18% drop in gross mortgage lending compared to January 2003.
Peter Williams, CML deputy director, emphasized this slowdown as evidence of the recent housing market contraction.
